item.title: Aggregate Supply and Demand
item.description: The [[economics/macroeconomics/Income-Expenditure Model|income-expenditure model]] aims to determine the short-run real GDP. The aggregate supply and demand model aims to determine the real GDP in both the short-run and long-run.

item.title: Asset Bubble
item.description: In finance and economic contexts, a ‘bubble’ is when the price for a class of assets, such as real estate, grows substantially over a short period of time, but largely as a result of ‘irrational exuberance’ and herd mentality.

item.title: Bonds
item.description: A bond is an I.O.U, a formal acknowledgement about a loan and its regular payments between the lender and borrower. Bonds are a type of [[finance/investment/Securities|security]] known as debt securities and are sometimes called ‘fixed-income securities’.

item.title: Business Cycle
item.description: Business cycles are the observed fluctations in production.

item.title: Cash Rate
item.description: The cash rate, which is set by the [[economics/macroeconomics/Central Bank|RBA]] as part of its [[economics/macroeconomics/Monetary Policy|monetary policy]], is a short-term interest rate charged on the ‘overnight’ loans between banks.

item.title: Central Bank
item.description: The central bank is a financial institution that is trusted with controlling the supply of money, implementing [[economics/macroeconomics/Monetary Policy|monetary policies]], and regulating the behaviour of [[economics/macroeconomics/Private Banks|private banks]] and other financial instutions through reserve requirements.

item.title: Economic Growth
item.description: Economic growth is the general improvement in living standards, which is representable through an indicator like real [[economics/macroeconomics/GDP|GDP]] per capita.

item.title: Exchange Rate
item.description: The exchange rate is the pricing of one country’s currency relative to other currencies. Bilateral nominal exchange rate is rate at which two countries can exchange their currencies.

item.title: Fiscal Policy
item.description: Fiscal policies are the policies around the usage of government income and expenditure in an effort to positively affect macroeconomic variables like [[economics/macroeconomics/Inflation|inflation]], [[economics/macroeconomics/Labour Market|unemployment rate]], etc.

item.title: GDP
item.description: GDP (gross domestic product) is the monetary value of all the domestically-produced final goods and services in a country during a given period.

item.title: Income-Expenditure Model
item.description: The income-expenditure model of GDP, also called the Keynesian model since it was pioneered by Keynes, is a model that asserts that the real GDP at equilibrium is entirely determined by the desired level of aggregate expenditure on domestically-produced final goods & services by all people, households, firms, foreigners and the government.

item.title: Inflation
item.description: Inflation describes a period where prices in an economy are increasing, or alternatively, the decline of the purchasing power of a country’s currency.

item.title: Interest
item.description: Interest is the cost of borrowing money. Borrowing money enables you to acquire goods and services that will produce value. Lending $$100$ is only worth doing with the expectation that you get some amount greater than $$100$ back.

item.title: International Trade
item.description: Balance of Payments The balance of payments is a record of transactions between residents and foreigners. It consists of the current account and the capital and financial account

item.title: Labour Market
item.description: The labour market, also called the job market, is the market for the supply of skills and time from employees and demand from businesses to hire those people.

item.title: Market
item.description: A market consists of all the buyers and sellers making transactions for a specific class of good or service. For instance, there is a wheat market, stock market, [[economics/macroeconomics/Labour Market|labour market]], even dating market… and so on.

item.title: Monetary Policy
item.description: Monetary policy is a modification of the [[economics/macroeconomics/Monetary Policy#Money Supply|supply of money]] by the [[economics/macroeconomics/Central Bank|Central bank]], usually in an effort to reduce [[economics/macroeconomics/Inflation|inflation]], [[economics/macroeconomics/Interest|interest rates]] or some other macroeconomic variable, and to ensure the stability of a country’s currency, minimal unemployment rate, and general welfare of citizens.

item.title: Money
item.description: Fundamentally, money is a: Medium of exchange — an asset that makes trading efficient by eliminating the inefficiencies of bartering, a form of trading where two parties exchange goods and relies on mutual desire of the others’ goods, called a double coincidence of wants.

item.title: Private Banks
item.description: Private banks are financial intermediaries that make household savings available for borrowing. When you make a deposit of physical currency to a bank, you are converting physical currency into an increase in the number representing the the value of your bank account.

item.title: Public Debt
item.description: Public debt, also called government debt or national debt, is the financial liabilities of the government. Since raising taxes is not always reasonable, nearly all governments have to borrow money from the [[economics/macroeconomics/Sectors|private sector]] to meet their expenses.

item.title: Quantity Theory
item.description: The quantity theory of money asserts that the price of goods and services is proportional to the money supply in the economy, assuming everything else is held constant.

item.title: Savings and Investments
item.description: Investment An investment, in macroeconomics, is the act of purchasing new capital goods to bolster productivity. Private investment — any investment made by households/businesses.

item.title: Sectors
item.description: Sectors are partitions of the economy that contain similar business activities. They might produce similar goods or services such as mining or farming.
